'''ERP Security''' is a wide range of measures aimed at protecting [[Enterprise resource planning]] (ERP) systems from illicit access ensuring accessibility and integrity of system data. ERP system is a computer software that serves to unify the information intended to manage the company including Production, [[Supply Chain Management]], [[Financial Management]], [[Human Resource Management]], [[Customer Relationship Management]], [[Enterprise Performance Management]], etc. Common ERP systems are [[SAP ERP|SAP]], [[Oracle E-Business Suite]], [[Microsoft Dynamics]].<ref name="ERP"> {{cite news |title=ERP (enterprise resource planning) |url=https://searcherp.techtarget.com/definition/ERP-enterprise-resource-planning |newspaper=SearchERP TechTarget|date=May 2017 |accessdate=6 April 2018}}</ref>
== Review == ERP system integrates business processes enabling procurement, payment, transport, human resources management, product management, and financial planning.<ref name="Oracle">{{cite web|url=https://www.oracle.com/applications/erp/what-is-erp.html|title=What Is ERP?|accessdate=6 April 2018}}</ref> As ERP system stores confidential information, [[ISACA]] recommends to regularly conduct a comprehensive assessment of ERP system security, checking ERP servers for software vulnerabilities, configuration errors, segregation of duties conflicts, compliance with relevant standards and recommendations, and recommendations of vendors.<ref>Security issues in ERP http://www.isaca.org/Knowledge-Center/Research/ResearchDeliverables/Pages/sap-erp.aspx </ref><ref name="Information Age"> {{cite news |title=Why security should be a priority for an ERP ecosystem |url=http://www.information-age.com/security-priority-erp-ecosystem-123468295/ |newspaper=Information Age|date=31 August 2017 |accessdate=6 April 2018}}</ref>
== Causes for vulnerabilities in ERP systems ==
=== Complexity === ERP systems process transactions and implement procedures to ensure that users have different access privileges. There are hundreds of authorization objects in SAP permitting users to perform actions in the system. In case of 200 users of the company, there are approximately 800,000 (100*2*20*200) ways to customize security settings of ERP systems.<ref>ERP Security and Segregation of Duties Audit: A Framework for Building an Automated Solution https://csbweb01.uncw.edu/people/ivancevichd/classes/MSA%20516/Extra%20Readings%20on%20Topics/Database/ERP%20Security.pdf</ref> With the growth of complexity, the possibility of errors and segregation of duties conflicts increases.<ref>Security issues in ERP http://www.isaca.org/Knowledge-Center/Research/ResearchDeliverables/Pages/sap-erp.aspx </ref>
=== Specificity === Vendors fix vulnerabilities on the regular basis since hackers monitor business applications to find and exploit security issues. SAP releases patches monthly on [[Patch Tuesday]], Oracle issues security fixes every quarter in [https://www.oracle.com/technetwork/topics/security/alerts-086861.html Oracle Critical Patch Update]. Business applications are becoming more exposed to the Internet or migrate to the cloud.<ref name="Forbes"> {{cite news |title=ERP Security Deserves Our Attention Now More Than Ever |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/forbestechcouncil/2017/07/07/erp-security-deserves-our-attention-now-more-than-ever/ |newspaper=Forbes |date=7 July 2017|accessdate=6 April 2018}}</ref>
=== Lack of competent specialists === ERP Cybersecurity survey<ref>ERP Cybersecurity survey 2017 https://erpscan.com/research/white-papers/erp-cybersecurity-survey-2017/</ref> revealed that organizations running ERP systems "lack both awareness and actions taken towards ERP security".<ref name="CSO"> {{cite news |title=Survey reveals the damage of fraud attacks against SAP system is estimated at $10m |url=https://www.cso.com.au/article/621185/survey-reveals-damage-fraud-attacks-against-sap-system-estimated-10m/|newspaper=CSO from IDG |date=27 June 2017|accessdate=6 April 2018}}</ref> ISACA states that "there is a shortage of staff members trained in ERP security"<ref>ERP Security and Segregation of Duties Audit: A Framework for Building an Automated Solution https://csbweb01.uncw.edu/people/ivancevichd/classes/MSA%20516/Extra%20Readings%20on%20Topics/Database/ERP%20Security.pdf</ref> and security services have the superficial understanding of risks and threats associated with ERP systems. Consequently, security vulnerabilities complicate undertakings such as detecting and subsequent fixing.<ref name="Forbes"> {{cite news |title=ERP Security Deserves Our Attention Now More Than Ever |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/forbestechcouncil/2017/07/07/erp-security-deserves-our-attention-now-more-than-ever/ |newspaper=Forbes |date=7 July 2017|accessdate=6 April 2018}}</ref><ref name="CloudComputing"> {{cite news |title=Six classic ERP system security problems – and how to avoid them |url=https://www.cloudcomputing-news.net/news/2017/may/10/six-classic-erp-system-security-problems-and-how-avoid-them/ |newspaper=CloudTech|date=10 May 2017|accessdate=6 April 2018}}</ref>
=== Lack of security auditing tools === ERP security audit is done manually as various tools with ERP packages do not provide means for system security auditing. Manual auditing is a complex and time-consuming process that increases the possibility of making a mistake.<ref>Security issues in ERP http://www.isaca.org/Knowledge-Center/Research/ResearchDeliverables/Pages/sap-erp.aspx </ref>
=== Large number of customized settings === The system includes thousands of parameters and fine settings including segregation of duties for transactions and tables, and the security parameters are set for every single system. ERP system settings are customized according to customers' requirements.
== Security issues in ERP systems == Security issues occur in ERP systems at different levels.
=== Network layer === '''Traffic interception and modification''' * absence of data encryption In 2011, Sensepost specialists analyzed DIAG protocol used in SAP ERP system for transferring data from the client to the SAP server. Two utilities were published that allowed to intercept, decrypt, and modify client-server requests containing critical information. This made attacks possible including [[Man-in-the-middle attack]]. The second utility operates like a Proxy and was created to identify new vulnerabilities. It allowed modifying requests coming to client and server.<ref>[http://erpscan.ru/press-center/press-release/erpscan-warns-about-new-vulnerabilities-of-diag-protocol-in-sap/ ERPScan warns about new vulnerabilities of DIAG protocol in SAP]</ref> * sending password in cleartext (SAP J2EE Telnet / Oracle listener old versions) In the SAP ERP system, it is possible to perform administering functions via [[Telnet]] protocol, which encrypts passwords.
''Vulnerabilities in encryption or authentication protocols''' * authentification by hash * XOR password encryption (SAP DIAG) * imposing the use of outdated authentication protocols * incorrect authentication protocols
'''Vulnerabilities in protocols (e.g. RFC in SAP ERP and Oracle Net in Oracle E-Business Suite).''' RFC protocol is used (Remote Function Call) to connect two systems by TCP/IP in SAP ERP. RFC call is a function that enables calling and running a functional module located in a system. The [[ABAP]] language that is used for writing business applications for SAP have functions to make RFC calls. Several critical vulnerabilities were found in SAP RFC Library versions 6.x and 7.x<ref>SAP RFC Library Multiple Vulnerabilities http://www.cnet.com/forums/post/7986898c-0a03-43d4-af70-b8427164c8e2</ref>: * RFC function "RFC_SET_REG_SERVER_PROPERTY" allows determining an exclusive use of RFC server. Vulnerability exploits lead to a denial of access for the legitimate users. [[DoS-attack|denial of service]] becomes possible. * Error in RFC function "SYSTEM_CREATE_INSTANCE". Exploiting vulnerability allows executing arbitrary code. * Error in RFC function "RFC_START_GUI". Exploiting vulnerability also allows executing arbitrary code. * Error in RFC function "RFC_START_PROGRAM". Exploiting vulnerability allows executing arbitrary code or gain information about RFC server configuration. * Error in RFC function "TRUSTED_SYSTEM_SECURITY". Exploiting vulnerability allows obtaining information about existing users and groups in RFC server.
=== Operating system level === OS software vulnerabilities * any remote vulnerability in OS is used to gain access to applications
Weak OS passwords * remote password brute-forcing * empty passwords for remote management tools like RAdmin and [[VNC]]
Insecure OS settings * NFS and SMB. SAP data becomes accessible to remote users via NFS an SMB * file access rights. Critical SAP and DBMS Oracle data files have insecure access rights such as 755 and 777 * insecure hosts settings. In the trusted hosts, servers can be listed and an attacker easily accesses them
=== Application vulnerabilities === ERP systems transfer more functionality on the web applications level with a lot of vulnerabilities: * Web application vulnerabilities ([[XSS]], [[XSRF]], [[SQL Injection]], Response Splitting, Code Execution) * Buffer overflow and format string in web-servers and application-servers (SAP IGS, SAP Netweaver, Oracle BEA Weblogic) * Insecure privileges for access (SAP Netweaver, SAP CRM, Oracle E-Business Suite)
== Role-based access control == In ERP systems, RBAC ([[Role-Based Access Control]]) model is applied for users to perform transactions and gain access to business objects.<ref>Security for Enterprise Resource Planning Systems http://www.utdallas.edu/~bxt043000/Publications/Journal-Papers/DAS/J46_Security_for_Enterprise_Resource_Planning_Systems.pdf </ref> In the model, the decision to grant access to a user is made based on the functions of users, or roles. Roles are a multitude of transactions the user or a group of users performs in the company. Transaction is a procedure of transforming system data, which helps perform this transaction. For any role, there is a number of corresponding users with one or multiple roles. Roles can be hierarchical. After the roles are implemented in the system, transactions corresponding to each role rarely change. The administrator needs to add or delete users from roles. The administrator provides a new user with a membership in one or more roles. When employees leave the organization, the administrator removes them from all the roles.<ref>Role-Based Access Controls http://csrc.nist.gov/rbac/ferraiolo-kuhn-92.pdf </ref>
== Segregation of Duties == Segregation or [[Separation of duties]], also known as SoD, is the concept according to which a user cannot make a transaction without other users (e.g. a user cannot add a new supplier, write out a cheque or pay to a supplier)<ref>ISACA Glossary Terms http://www.isaca.org/Knowledge-Center/Lists/ISACA%20Glossary%20Terms/DispForm.aspx?ID=1700</ref> and a risk of fraud is much lower.<ref>A risk-based approach to segregation of duties http://www.ey.com/Publication/vwLUAssets/EY_Segregation_of_duties/$FILE/EY_Segregation_of_dutie/s.pdf</ref> SoD can be implemented by RBAC mechanisms, and a notion of mutually exclusive roles is introduced. For instance, to pay a supplier, one user initiates payment procedure and another accepts it.<ref>R. A. Botha and J. H. P. Eloff [http://www.research.ibm.com/journal/sj/403/botha.html Separation of Duties for Access Control Enforcement in Workflow Environments]</ref> In this case, initiating payment and accepting are mutually exclusive roles. Segregation of duties can be either static or dynamic. With static SoD (SSoD), a user cannot belong to two mutually exclusive roles. With dynamic SoD (DSoD), a user does but cannot perform them within one transaction. Both of them have their own advantages. SSoD is simple, while DSoD is flexible.<ref>Simple Search http://www.bth.se/fou/cuppsats.nsf/all/52d12689b4758c84c12572a600386f1d/$file/mcs-2006-16.pdf</ref> Segregation of Duties is explained in SoD matrix. X and Y matrixes describe system roles. If the two roles are mutually exclusive, there is a flag at the interception of the corresponding rows and columns.
== ERP Security scanners == ERP Security scanner is a software intended to search for vulnerabilities in ERP systems. Scanner analyzes configurations of ERP system, searches for misconfigurations, access control and encryption conflicts, insecure components, and checks for updates. The scanner checks system parameters for compliance with the manufacturer's recommendations and auditing procedures [[:en:ISACA|ISACA]]. ERP Security scanners produce reports with the vulnerabilities listed according to their criticality. The examples of scanners: * [http://erpscan.com ERPScan] for [[SAP ERP|SAP]] ERP * [http://www.onapsis.com Onapsis] for [[SAP ERP|SAP]] ERP * [http://www.integrigy.com/products/appsentry AppSentry] for [[Oracle E-Business Suite]] * [http://www.ptsecurity.ru MaxPatrol] for [[SAP ERP|SAP]] ERP

{{pp-pc1|small=yes}} {{Use dmy dates|date=July 2012}} The '''eightfold path''' is a method of [[policy analysis]] assembled by [[Eugene Bardach]], a professor at the [[Goldman School of Public Policy]] at the [[University of California, Berkeley]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Eugene Bardach {{!}} Emeritus Professor of Public Policy|url=https://gspp.berkeley.edu/directories/faculty/eugene-bardach|publisher=University of California at Berkeley}}</ref> It is outlined in his book ''A Practical Guide for Policy Analysis: The Eightfold Path to More Effective Problem Solving'', which is now in its fourth edition.<ref>{{cite web|title=CQ Press: Book: A Practical Guide for Policy Analysis: The Eightfold Path to More Effective Problem Solving, 4th Edition, Eugene Bardach |url=http://www.cqpress.com/product/Bardach4e.html |publisher=CQ Press |accessdate=29 October 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20111010053147/http://www.cqpress.com/product/Bardach4e.html |archivedate=10 October 2011 |df=dmy }}</ref> The book is commonly referenced in [[Policy|public policy]] and [[public administration]] scholarship.<ref>{{cite web|title=List of scholarly works referencing ''A Practical Guide for Policy Analysis''|url=https://scholar.google.com/scholar?cites=4884126323094470718&as_sdt=20005&sciodt=0,9&hl=en|publisher=Google Scholar|accessdate=6 August 2011}}</ref>
Bardach's procedure is as follows: # Define the problem # Assemble some evidence # Construct the alternatives # Select the criteria # Project the outcomes # Confront the trade-offs # Decide # Tell your story
A possible ninth step, based on Bardach's own writing, might be "repeat steps 1 - 8 as necessary."
== The New York taxi driver test == The New York taxi driver test is a technique for evaluating the effectiveness of communication between policy makers and analysts. Bardach contends that policy explanations must be clear and down-to-earth enough for a taxi driver to be able to understand the premise during a trip through city streets. The New York taxi driver is presumed to be both a non-specialist and a tough customer.<ref>{{cite book| last = Bardach| first = Eugene| title = A practical guide for policy analysis: the eightfold path to more effective problem solving| year = 2000| publisher = Chatham House Publishers, Seven Bridges Press| isbn = 978-1-889119-29-8 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ebriefings.ca/wordpress/?p%3D321 |accessdate=13 May 2012 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110712110533/http://www.ebriefings.ca/wordpress/?p=321 |archivedate=12 July 2011 |title=Digital Fishers – The Taxi Driver Pitch }}</ref>

'''Gemma Weedall''' (b. 1989) is a South Australian social and environmental [[Activism|activist]], journalist, photographer, opinion writer and community organiser.
== Career == Weedall graduated from the [[University of Adelaide]] with a Bachelor of Social Sciences in 2009. While studying, she was involved in student politics and environmental activism through her position as Environment Officer on the Student Representative Council and as convenor of several groups and collectives. She was an active member of the Climate Emergency Action Network (CLEAN) and the socialist youth organisation [[Resistance (socialist youth organisation)|Resistance]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.greenleft.org.au/node/44262|title=‘Real power comes from the grassroots’ {{!}} Green Left Weekly|website=www.greenleft.org.au|access-date=2016-07-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.greenleft.org.au/content/free-speech-dead-long-live-sedition|title=Free speech is dead: long live sedition! {{!}} Green Left Weekly|last=|first=|date=2005-12-07|website=www.greenleft.org.au|publisher=|access-date=2016-11-19}}</ref> After graduating, she stood as the [[Socialist Alliance (Australia)|Socialist Alliance]] candidate for the seat of Adelaide in the [[Australian federal election, 2010|2010 Australian Federal election]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://backstory.org.au/wordpress/?p=643 |title=Back Story » Blog Archive » Gemma Weedall and Renfrey Clark on the Federal Election 2010 |date=2011-02-20 |access-date=2016-07-26 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110220201225/http://backstory.org.au/wordpress/?p=643 |archivedate=2011-02-20 |df= }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.greenleft.org.au/content/alps-desperate-rebadging-could-mask-shift-right|title=ALP's desperate rebadging could mask a shift to right {{!}} Green Left Weekly|website=www.greenleft.org.au|access-date=2016-11-19}}</ref> but was unsuccessful.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.abc.net.au/elections/federal/2010/guide/adel.htm|title=Adelaide - 2010 Federal Election - ABC News (Australian Broadcasting Corporation)|website=www.abc.net.au|access-date=2016-11-19}}</ref>
She has been an active member of numerous activist groups in South Australia, where she has often held leadership positions. These include Resistance,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://radioadelaidebreakfast.wordpress.com/tag/gemma-weedall/|title=Gemma Weedall {{!}} Breakfast on Radio Adelaide|website=radioadelaidebreakfast.wordpress.com|access-date=2016-07-26}}</ref> Socialist Alliance, the Climate Emergency Action Network (CLEAN)<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.cleansa.org/2013/03/unconventional-gas-in-sa-a-road-to-nowhere/|title=Unconventional Gas in SA – A Road to Nowhere? {{!}} Climate Emergency Action Network|website=www.cleansa.org|access-date=2016-07-26}}</ref> and Repower Port Augusta (as a representative of CLEAN).<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.repowerportaugusta.org/node/11|title=Update: Parliamentary briefing and the Repower Port Augusta local group {{!}} Repower Port Augusta|website=www.repowerportaugusta.org|access-date=2016-07-26}}</ref> As of 2015, she had been a member of CLEAN for seven years,<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.greenleft.org.au/node/60432|title=Movement leaders feature at Radical Ideas conf {{!}} Green Left Weekly|website=www.greenleft.org.au|access-date=2016-07-26}}</ref> and continues to advocate for renewable energy projects in South Australia with an emphasis on solar thermal potential for [[Port Augusta|Port Augusta, South Australia]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://bze.org.au/media/radio/trillions-be-invested-new-renewable-technology-160202|title=Trillions to be Invested in New Renewable Technology {{!}} Beyond Zero Emissions|website=bze.org.au|access-date=2016-07-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.transcontinental.com.au/story/3248664/solar-thermal-still-on-radar-for-port-augusta/|title=Solar thermal still on radar for Port Augusta|last=|first=|date=2015-07-30|website=|publisher=The Transcontinental|access-date=2016-07-26}}</ref>
In 2015, she participated in a hunger strike to show solidarity for refugees detained at [[Manus Regional Processing Centre|Manus Island]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.telesurtv.net/english/news/Australian-Activists-Join-Manus-Island-Refugee-Hunger-Strike-20150120-0005.html|title=Australian Activists Join Manus Island Refugee Hunger Strike|access-date=2016-07-26}}</ref>
She is a regular journalist,<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.greenleft.org.au/node/45994|title=Can we save the Murray Darling? {{!}} Green Left Weekly|last=Weedall|first=Gemma|date=|website=www.greenleft.org.au|publisher=|access-date=2016-07-26}}</ref> opinion writer<ref name=":1">{{Cite web|url=https://www.greenleft.org.au/node/53215|title=Why we need an ecosocialist revolution {{!}} Green Left Weekly|last=Weedall|first=Gemma|date=|website=www.greenleft.org.au|publisher=|access-date=2016-07-26}}</ref> and photo contributor<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.greenleft.org.au/content/build-political-alternative-better-world|title=Build the political alternative for a better world {{!}} Green Left Weekly|website=www.greenleft.org.au|access-date=2016-11-19}}</ref> to [[Green Left Weekly]]<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.greenleft.org.au/taxonomy/term/2991|title=Gemma Weedall {{!}} Green Left Weekly|website=www.greenleft.org.au|access-date=2016-07-26}}</ref> and is an occasional speaker on political topics.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://vimeo.com/30250728|title=Can Labor's Carbon Price Green the Economy?|website=Vimeo|access-date=2016-07-26}}</ref><ref>{{Citation|last=GreenLeftTV|title=Gemma Weedall: Why the Market can't fix the climate crisis|date=2014-04-27|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=QzHmhdD5Dcc|accessdate=2016-07-26}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.socialismforthe21stcentury.org/gemma-weedall|title=Gemma Weedall {{!}} Socialism for the 21st Century|website=www.socialismforthe21stcentury.org|access-date=2016-07-26}}</ref>
Weedall describes herself as an [[Eco-socialism|eco-socialist]].<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" />

[[Populism]]
[[Pro-Europeanism]]{{cite news |title=Georgia: political parties and the EU |url=http://www.europarl.europa.eu/RegData/etudes/ATAG/2015/545743/EPRS_ATA(2015)545743_REV1_EN.pdf |agency=European Parliamentary Research Service}}
Factions:
[[Economic liberalism]]{{cite book |last1=Kakachia |first1=Kornely |title=The First 100 Days of The Georgian Dream Government: A Reality Check |date=2017 |publisher=Georgian Institute of Politics |location=Tbilisi, Georgia |url=http://expertpolls.ge/wp-content/uploads/2017/02/Report_2017.pdf |quote=One should not forget that, despite having a strong liberal wing, GD views itself as a center-left party and is an observer member of the Party of European Socialists (PES) in the European Parliament.}}
[[Social conservatism]]http://carnegieeurope.eu/strategiceurope/64926 | headquarters = [[Tbilisi]], [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]] | international = [[Progressive Alliance]]http://progressive-alliance.info/2810-2/ | website = {{URL|http://41.ge/}} | country = Georgia | native_name = {{lang|ka|ქართული ოცნება – დემოკრატიული საქართველო}} | leader1_title = Chairperson | leader1_name = [[Bidzina Ivanishvili]] | founder = [[Bidzina Ivanishvili]] | position = [[Big tent]] {{small|(de facto)}}
{{nowrap|[[Centre-left]] {{small|(self-described)}}{{cite web|title=About The Party|url=http://41.ge/About-Us|website=41.ge|publisher=Georgian Dream - Democratic Georgia|accessdate=25 January 2018}}}} | european = [[Party of European Socialists]] (observer) | colours = {{Color box|#004a99|border=darkgray}} {{Color box|#FFBF00|border=darkgray}} [[Blue]], [[Amber (color)|amber]] | slogan = ''"თავისუფლება, სწრაფი განვითარება, კეთილდღეობა"'' (Freedom, Rapid Development, Welfare) | seats1_title = Seats in [[Parliament of Georgia|Parliament]] | seats1 = {{Composition bar|114|150|hex=#004a99}}[http://www.civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=28157 Key Facts and Procedures on Govt No-Confidence Vote, Sought by UNM] | country_dab1 = Politics of Georgia (country) }} '''Georgian Dream – Democratic Georgia''' ({{lang-ka|ქართული ოცნება – დემოკრატიული საქართველო}}, ''Kartuli ocneba – Demok’rat’iuli Sakartvelo'') is the governing party of [[Georgia (country)|Georgia]]. The party was established on 19 April 2012 by the billionaire businessman and politician [[Bidzina Ivanishvili]].{{cite book|author=Stephen Jones|chapter=Preface to the Paperback Edition|title=Georgia: A Political History Since Independence|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=hcMZCAAAQBAJ&pg=PR11|year=2015|publisher=I.B.Tauris|isbn=978-1-78453-085-3 |pages=11}} It is the leading party of the six-party Georgian Dream [[political alliance|political coalition]] which won the [[Georgian parliamentary election, 2012|2012 parliamentary election]]. The political party Georgian Dream – Democratic Georgia currently has 115 seats in the 150-seat Georgian parliament. ==History== The party evolved from the public movement Georgian Dream, launched by Ivanishvili as a platform for his political activities in December 2011. Since Ivanishvili was not a Georgian citizen at the moment of the party's inaugural session, the lawyer [[Manana Kobakhidze]] was elected as an interim, nominal chairman of the Georgian Dream – Democratic Georgia. The party also includes several notable Georgians such as the politician [[Sozar Subari]], former diplomat [[Tedo Japaridze]], chess grandmaster [[Zurab Azmaiparashvili]], security commentator Irakli Sesiashvili, writer Guram Odisharia and famed [[Association football|footballer]] [[Kakha Kaladze]].[http://ca.news.yahoo.com/shevchenko-hangs-boots-politics-143548518--sow.html Shevchenko hangs up boots for politics]{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, AFP (28 July 2012) The party successfully challenged the ruling [[United National Movement (Georgia)|United National Movement]] (UMN) in the [[Georgian parliamentary election, 2012|2012 parliamentary election]], pledging to increase welfare spending and pursue a more pragmatic foreign policy with Russia.[http://civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=24683 Ivanishvili's Political Party Launched]. Civil Georgia. 21 April 2012. Retrieved 12 May 2012. It won this election in coalition with six other opposition parties, with 54.97% of the vote, being allotted 85 seats in parliament. The governing UMN took 40.34%. [[President of Georgia|President]] [[Mikheil Saakashvili]] conceded that his party lost, and pledged to support the constitutional process of forming a new government.{{cite web|last=Barry |first=Ellen |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/10/03/world/europe/georgia-election-results.html?ref=global-home |title=Georgia’s President Concedes Defeat in Parliamentary Election |location=Georgia (Georgian Republic) |publisher=NYTimes.com |date=2012-10-02 |accessdate=2012-12-07}} In April 2017 senior MP Gedevan Popkhadze threatened to quit the party for its endorsement of an opposition-nominated candidate to the supervisory board of the [[Georgia Public Broadcasting|Georgian Public Broadcaster]].{{cite web|title=Senior MP Ponders Quitting Georgian Dream|url=https://old.civil.ge/eng/article.php?id=31008|website=Civil.Ge|publisher=civil.ge|accessdate=24 May 2018}} Popkhadze criticized the candidate on account of her anti-clerical activism. The incident is seen as an internal conflict between long-time GD members which joined the party while it was in opposition and a new group of members who were installed in high positions prior to the 2016 parliamentary elections. The news agency [[Democracy and Freedom Watch]] related the incident to the return of Bidzina Ivanishvili as chairman of the party later that month, which furthermore was perceived as a move to maintain the unity of the coalition.{{cite news|last1=DFWatch Staff|title=Ivanishvili to make political comeback, will head Georgia’s ruling GD|url=http://dfwatch.net/ivanishvili-make-political-comeback-will-head-georgias-ruling-gd-50262|accessdate=24 May 2018|agency=Democracy and Freedom Watch|date=Apr 26, 2018}} In August 2018 Chairman of the [[Georgian Parliament]] [[Irakli Kobakhidze]] announced that the party will nominate no candidate for 2018 presidential elections. Instead it is supporting the independent candidate [[Salome Zurabishvili]]. ==Ideology== Like many [[party of power|parties of power]] the Georgian Dream lacks a clear ideology. The reasons given for this range from the party’s history as an all-encompassing front of people opposed to the UNM government to the standard opportunism associated with such parties. For example, the [[Heinrich Böll Foundation]] described it as "a party of nomenclature, public servants, ‘intelligentsia’, medium and large businessmen, and technocrats – a party, which is held together through loyalty to its charismatic leader and the opposition to the government of the ‘Rose Revolution.’"{{cite web|last1=Lortkipanidze|first1=Levan|title=Parliamentary Elections in Georgia|url=https://ge.boell.org/en/2016/10/13/parliamentary-elections-georgia|website=ge.boell.org|publisher=Heinrich Böll Foundation|accessdate=25 January 2018}} In addition, it has been reported that left-wing activists view the party as “ideologically amorphous” in contrast to the party's own self-identification with the left itself.{{cite web|last=Pertaia |first=Luka |url=http://oc-media.org/are-georgias-disparate-left-wing-protesters-consolidating-into-a-coherent-political-force/ |title=Are Georgia’s disparate left-wing protesters consolidating into a coherent political force? |location=Georgia (Georgian Republic) |website=oc-media.org |date=2017-02-16}} Under their majority the constitution was amended to define marriage solely as "a union between a woman and a man for the purpose of creating a family.”[https://jamestown.org/program/georgias-ruling-party-supermajority-passes-unilateral-constitutional-reform/ Georgia's Ruling Party 'Supermajority' Passes Unilateral Constitutional Reform] Yet at the same time the party passed legislation banning discrimination against LGBT individuals, making Georgia the most LGBT-friendly country in the South Caucasus on paper.https://ge.boell.org/sites/default/files/emc_legal_situation_of_lgbti_persons_in_georgia_eng.pdf According to the Georgian Institute of Politics, Georgian Dream's economic policy comprises a combination of the pre-existing free market model, created by their predecessors, with a comprehensive "centre-left" safety net.{{cite news |title=The First 100 Days of the Georgian Dream Government: A Reality Check |url=http://gip.ge/the-first-100-days-of-the-georgian-dream-government-a-reality-check/ |accessdate=7 June 2018 |agency=Georgian Institute of Politics |date=2017-02-22}} ==Georgian Dream coalition== Georgian Dream – Democratic Georgia party is the leading member of the Georgian Dream Coalition, which initially included six political parties of diverse ideological orientations.{{Citation |title=Georgia’s election: Pain and grief in Georgia |newspaper=The Economist |date=29 September 2012 |url=http://www.economist.com/node/21563789}}{{Citation |first=Thomas |last=de Waal |title=A Crucial Election in Georgia |publisher=Carnegie Endowment for International Peace |date=11 September 2012 |url=http://carnegieendowment.org/2012/09/11/crucial-election-in-georgia/drlp}} The coalition was made up of pro-market and pro-western liberals, radical nationalists with [[xenophobia|xenophobic]] rhetoric, and former representatives of the [[Eduard Shevardnadze|Shevardnadze]] administration who were disempowered during the [[Rose Revolution]] of 2003.{{Citation |first=Thomas |last=de Waal |title=Georgia Holds Its Breath |newspaper=Foreign Policy |date=26 September 2012 |url=https://foreignpolicy.com/articles/2012/09/26/georgia_holds_its_breath?page=0,0 |access-date=7 March 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20131110152600/http://www.foreignpolicy.com/articles/2012/09/26/georgia_holds_its_breath?page=0,0# |archive-date=10 November 2013 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} The name of the alliance is inspired by a rap song by Ivanishvili's son [[Bera (rapper)|Bera]].{{cite web |url=http://www.baltimoresun.com/news/nation-world/sns-rt-us-georgia-election-factboxbre88t0iw-20120930,0,2550976.story |title=Topic Galleries |publisher=baltimoresun.com |date= |accessdate=2012-12-07 }}{{dead link|date=October 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite web|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/georgia-brink-odd-parliamentary-election-leads-angst-over-results-798509?page=3 |title=Georgia On Brink: Odd Parliamentary Election Leads To Angst Over Results |publisher=Ibtimes.com |accessdate=2012-12-07}} ===Constituent parties=== *Georgian Dream – Democratic Georgia - 97 seats *[[Conservative Party of Georgia]] - 6 seats *[[Social Democrats for the Development of Georgia]]- 6 seats *[[Green Party of Georgia]]- 6 seats ===Former constituent parties=== *[[Our Georgia – Free Democrats]] - 8 seats (left the coalition and became an opposition party on 5 November 2014) *[[National Forum (Georgia)|National Forum]] - 6 seats (left the coalition after convention where majority of party members voted to leave on 3 April 2016) *[[Republican Party of Georgia]] - 10 seats (left the coalition before the 2016 election) ==Electoral performance== {| class="wikitable" <!-- Deleted image removed: [[Image:HavenLogo1.jpg|thumb|right|]] --> The '''Haven Institute''' is a residential learning centre situated on [[Gabriola Island]] in the Gulf Islands of British Columbia on the west coast of Canada. Founded by [[Jock McKeen]] and [[Bennet Wong]], the centre offers programs for personal and professional purposes, including Certificate and Diploma Programs in Group Facilitation and Counselling Skills.
==Institutional Registration and Credits==
''The Haven Institute'' is registered in the province of [[British Columbia]] as a Private Post-Secondary institution in accordance with the ''Private Post-Secondary Education Act of B.C. (SBC CHAP 64)''. This registration is governed by the [[Private Career Training Institutions Agency|Private Career Training Institutions Agency of B.C.]]. Some of their programs are approved for [[Continuing Professional Development|continuing education credit]] by the ''Canadian Addiction Counsellors Certification Federation (CACCF)'', the ''Canadian Association of Rehabilitation Professionals (CARP)'', and the ''Canadian Counselling Association (CCA)'' and the ''College of Massage Therapists of British Columbia (CMTBC)''.
==History==
In 1983, two physicians, [[Bennet Wong]] and [[Jock McKeen]] purchased the ''Taylor Bay Lodge'' on [[Gabriola Island, British Columbia]], and transformed it into a waterfront resort and conference centre.<ref>*{{Citation | last =Littleton | first =Ellery | author-link = | publication-date = | title =A Resort with A Difference | newspaper=Monday Magazine | publication-place=Victoria, BC | date=November 28, 1985 | volume=11 | issue=49 | pages = }}.</ref> They called it "a resort with a difference" because people could enter into the activities at whatever level they chose. Some people came with their families to enjoy a country resort; groups and agencies held conferences; others attended the numerous residential [[self-awareness]] seminars. Still others returned for training in counseling; currently, 95 people have graduated from the Diploma program offered by ''The Haven Institute''.<ref>*{{Citation |last = Fewster |first = Gerry |title = Ben and Jock |newspaper = The Sounder |publication-place = Gabriola, BC |date = December 20, 2001 |url = http://www.soundernews.com/content/archives/2001-12-19/ben_and_jock.htm |page = 3 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110716111618/http://www.soundernews.com/content/archives/2001-12-19/ben_and_jock.htm |archivedate = July 16, 2011 |df = }}.</ref>
There are over fifty visiting faculty members teaching in this nontraditional, open atmosphere. Some notable ones have been [[Virginia Satir]], [[Gestalt therapy#The Polsters|Erv and Miriam Polster]], [[Paul Reps]], [[Carl Whitaker]], Paul Lowe, [[James Bugental]], [[Thomas Szasz]], [[Bill O'Hanlon]], [[Maria Gomori]] and Joanna Macy. The Haven Symposium has featured [[Joseph Chilton Pearce]],<ref>*{{Citation |last = Cameron |first = Brent |author-link = |publication-date = |title = Interview with Joseph Chilton Pearce |newspaper = Common Ground |publication-place = Vancouver, BC |date = March 2005 |volume = |issue = |url = http://www.commonground.ca/iss/0503164/cg164_Pearce.shtml |pages = |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090109130010/http://www.commonground.ca/iss/0503164/cg164_Pearce.shtml |archivedate = 2009-01-09 |df = }}. </ref> [[Margaret Wheatley]],<ref>*{{Citation |last = Wheatley |first = Margaret |author-link = |last2 = Kellner-Rogers |first2 = Myron |title = Community: The Promise and the Paradox |newspaper = Common Ground |publication-place = Vancouver, BC |date = March 2006 |volume = |issue = |url = http://www.commonground.ca/iss/0603176/cg176_wheatley.shtml |page = |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070614123841/http://commonground.ca/iss/0603176/cg176_wheatley.shtml |archivedate = 2007-06-14 |df = }}.</ref> and [[Dan Millman]].<ref>*{{Citation | last =Common Ground | first =Staff Writer | author-link = | title=Interview With Dan Millman | newspaper=Common Ground | publication-place=Vancouver, BC | date=March 2007 | volume= | issue= | page= }}.</ref><ref>*{{Citation |last = Izzard |first = Denese |author-link = |publication-date = |title = The Haven's First Symposium Alive and Well |newspaper = The Sounder |publication-place = Gabriola, BC |date = November 13, 2003 |volume = |issue = |url = http://www.soundernews.com/fullstory/EpyllFZkFEYRvBEQBO.shtml |pages = 8 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110716111622/http://www.soundernews.com/fullstory/EpyllFZkFEYRvBEQBO.shtml |archivedate = July 16, 2011 |df = }}.</ref> The Wong-McKeen Phoenix Auditorium, Haven's performing arts theatre, has seen performances by [[Ann Mortifee]], [[Laurie Anderson]], [[Eric Bibb]], [[Victor Wooten]], [[Shari Ulrich]] and [[Leon Bibb (musician)|Leon Bibb]].<ref>*{{Citation |last = Mason |first = Bruce |author-link = |publication-date = |title = The Legendary Leon Bibb: A Step Ahead at GES |newspaper = The Sounder |publication-place = Gabriola, BC |date = February 11, 2008 |volume = |issue = |url = http://www.soundernews.com/fullstory/EkpkZuApVyOxBzrCDj.shtml |pages = |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110716111611/http://www.soundernews.com/fullstory/EkpkZuApVyOxBzrCDj.shtml |archivedate = July 16, 2011 |df = }}.</ref> ''The Haven Institute Press'' publishes books by founders [[Bennet Wong]] and [[Jock McKeen]] and others.<ref>*{{Citation | last =Niosi | first = Goody. | author-link = | publication-date = | date=August 31, 2005 | title =Haven Founders Offer Tips on Happiness | newspaper=Harbour City Star | publication-place=Nanaimo, BC | pages = A4 }}.</ref>
The Core Programs for the Institute were developed by McKeen and Wong. Programs have been offered at The Haven with Chinese translation since the early 1990s, and numerous Asian people have attended as participants, and trainees. <ref>*{{Citation | last =Tao | first =Cora | author-link = | publication-date = | title =Haven and the Phase Program | newspaper=Broadcasting Monthly | publication-place=Taipei, Taiwan | date=September 1993 | volume= | issue= | pages = }}.</ref><ref>*{{Citation | last =Assaf | first =M | author-link = | publication-date = | title =Haven self-development programs foster international relationships | newspaper=Nanaimo News Bulletin | publication-place=Nanaimo, BC | date=December 24, 2011 | pages =11 }}.</ref>[[Joann Peterson]] became the Director of Education in 1992, and oversaw the training of over 1200 interns and assistants in group and individual counselling until her death in 2007. The programs have continued to develop and broaden.<ref>*{{Citation | last =Campbell | first =Leslie | author-link = | publication-date = | title =Joann Peterson - The Resilient Life | newspaper=Focus Magazine | publication-place=Victoria, BC | date=October 2005 | volume=18 | issue=1 | pages =46–49 }}.</ref>
In 2003, The ''Haven Foundation'' was established as a federally recognized Canadian [[Non-profit organization|nonprofit charity]]. In 2004, Wong and McKeen and their three sons, transferred the ownership of ''The Haven Institute'' into the ''Haven Foundation'' so that the facility and their work could continue in perpetuity under independent guidance.,<ref>*{{Citation | last =Nanaimo Daily News | first =Staff Writer. | author-link = | publication-date = | title =Haven Foundation Continues Mandate | newspaper=Nanaimo Daily News | publication-place=Nanaimo, BC | date=January 23, 2004 | pages =A4 }}.</ref> In 2008 The Haven Institute celebrated its 25th anniversary.<ref>*{{Citation | last =Wilson | first = Valerie. | author-link = | publication-date = | date=March 12, 2008 | title =Haven Marks 25 Years of Altering Lives | newspaper=Harbour City Star | publication-place=Nanaimo, BC | pages =A17 }}. </ref> Participants from all over the world continue to attend both the core programs and other programs offered by visiting faculty. The Haven hosted the ''TEDx Gabriola'' conference in March 2013.<ref>*{{Citation | last =Cerminara | first =Alina | author-link = | publication-date = | title =TEDx Gabriola inspires islanders | newspaper=The Flying Shingle | publication-place=Gabriola, BC | date=March 25, 2013 | volume=41 | issue=12 | url =http://www.FlyingShingle.com/cgi-bin/coranto/viewnews.cgi?id=20130325574386923573 | pages =1,3 }}.</ref> <ref>*{{Citation | last =Stajic | first =Janina | author-link = | publication-date = | title =To be empathic or not, that is the question | newspaper=The Sounder | publication-place=Gabriola, BC | date=March 25, 2013 | volume=23 | issue=12 | url =http://www.soundernews.com/opinions-letters/to-be-empathic-or-not-that-is-the-question.html | pages =4 }}.</ref>
==Teaching principles==
The methods in the courses are derived from a great variety of sources in the fields of [[humanistic psychology]] and [[transpersonal psychology]], as well as the more traditional fields of [[psychology]], [[religious studies]], [[drama]], [[music]] and [[art]]. The techniques used cover a broad spectrum, including [[Gestalt therapy|gestalt]], [[Body psychotherapy|Reichian]] body approaches, [[acupuncture]], [[psychodrama]], [[psychosynthesis]], role playing, [[family therapy]], fantasy and visualization techniques, video work, [[theatre games]], [[play therapy]] and [[music therapy]], all stressing [[Encounter group|encounter]] and [[communication]] skills. The approaches are [[educational]] only, so no [[therapeutic]] care is available.<ref>*{{Citation | last =Fayerman | first =Pamela | author-link = | publication-date = | title =Breaking the Silence Over Depression | newspaper=Vancouver Sun | publication-place=Vancouver, BC | date=October 7, 1998 | volume= | issue= | pages =B03 }}.</ref> <ref>*{{Citation | last =Walton | first =Paul | author-link = | publication-date = | title =From Haven House to the Haven, Awareness is the Key | newspaper=Nanaimo Daily News | publication-place=Nanaimo, BC | date=March 9, 2010 | pages = }}. </ref> There are some lectures and discussion groups, but emphasis is upon [[heuristic|heuristic education]] and [[experiential learning]], in which the person is invited to experience situations in which to learn what is needed.<ref>*{{Citation | last =Allen | first =Wayne | author-link = | last2 = | first2 = | author2-link = | publication-date = | date = | year =2005 | title =This Endless Moment | edition = | volume = | series = | publication-place =Waterloo, ON | place = | publisher =Phoenix Centre Press | pages =xi, 20–24, 45–46, 91 | page = | id = | isbn =0-9684446-2-8 | doi = | oclc =56532288 | url = | accessdate = }}. </ref>

{{Infobox journal | title = Health and Human Rights | cover = | editor = [[Paul Farmer]] | discipline = [[Public health]], [[human rights]] | former_names = | abbreviation = Health Hum. Rights | publisher = [[Harvard University Press]] | country = United States | frequency = Biannual | history = 1994–present | openaccess = | license = | impact = | impact-year = | website = http://www.hhrjournal.org | link1 = http://www.hhrjournal.org | link1-name = Online access | link2 = https://www.hhrjournal.org/archives/ | link2-name = Online archive | JSTOR = 10790969 | OCLC = 243563202 | LCCN = 94648723 | CODEN = HHRIF4 | ISSN = 1079-0969 | eISSN = 2150-4113 }} '''''Health and Human Rights''''' is a biannual [[peer review|peer-reviewed]] [[public health journal]] that was established in 1994. It covers research on the conceptual foundations of [[human rights]] and [[social justice]] in relation to health. The founding [[editor-in-chief]] was [[Jonathan Mann (WHO official)|Jonathan Mann]], who was succeeded by [[Sofia Gruskin]] in 1997. Since 2007, the journal is edited by [[Paul Farmer]]. [[Harvard University Press]] became the publisher of the journal in 2013,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://harvardfxbcenter.org/harvard-university-press-publishes-hhr-journal/ |title=FXB Center for Health and Human Rights, Harvard University Press Partner on Health and Human Rights: An International Journal |publisher=Harvardfxbcenter.org |date= |accessdate=2013-07-01}}</ref> succeeding the François-Xavier Bagnoud Center for Health and Human Rights at [[Harvard School of Public Health]].
The journal transitioned to an online [[Open access (publishing)|open-access publication]] in the summer of 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.harvardfxbcenter.org/resources-hhr-journal.php |title=FXB Center for Health and Human Rights | Harvard School of Public Health | Harvard University |publisher=Harvardfxbcenter.org |date= |accessdate=2012-11-01}}</ref> It includes two sections: "Critical Concepts" and "Health and Human Rights in Practice". The first focuses on the conceptual foundations and challenges of rights discourse and action in relation to health. The second encourages and promotes new voices from the field — highlighting the innovative work of groups and individuals in direct engagement with human rights struggles as they relate to health.

This article provides a listing of applications that include [[Homeless Management Information Systems|Homeless Management Information System]] (HMIS) functionality. Although the [[United States Department of Housing and Urban Development]] (HUD) requires that Continuums of Care (CoCs) receiving HUD funds for homeless services implement an HMIS for data collection and reporting purposes, they do not require the use of any one application. Rather, they require that the data be collected in a manner consistent with the HMIS Data Standards and that they generate key reports such as the HUD Annual Performance Report (APR) and the [[Annual Homeless Assessment Report to Congress|Annual Homeless Assessment Report]] (AHAR). The APR is a program-level report that includes information about data quality, demographic data related to clients served, and performance indicators of a program's success in working with clients. The AHAR is a broader report which is submitted at the CoC level and aggregated at a national level. Any application that collects data consistent with HUD's published data standards and generates the required reports may be considered an HMIS. Although HUD has released data standards and programming specifications for some reports, HUD does not endorse or explicitly approve any HMIS application. {{creationism2}} The '''International Conference on Creationism''' ('''ICC''') is a conference in support of [[young earth creationism]],<ref name=discover>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.discovermagazine.com/realitybase/2008/08/18/annual-creationism-conference-takes-scientific-approach/ |title=Creationism Conference Takes "Scientific" Approach|format= Blogs / Reality Base |publisher=Discover Magazine|ref=harv}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|newspaper=[[Philadelphia Inquirer]]|date= August 3, 1990|title=Group Seeks a Scientific Creationism|ref=harv}}</ref> sponsored by the Creation Science Fellowship (CSF). The first conference occurred in 1986 at [[Duquesne University]] in Pittsburgh. Subsequent conferences have been held in 1990, 1994, 1998, 2003, 2008, and 2013;<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.creationicc.org/about.htm|title=About the ICC}}</ref> The next conference will be held in 2018.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.creationicc.org|title=ICC Home Page}}</ref>

==Mission== The primary mission of the Tower Center is to promote the study of politics and international affairs and to stimulate an interest in ethical public service among undergraduates. The Tower Center is an academic center where all parties and views are heard in a [[marketplace of ideas]], and the Center pursues its mission in a non partisan manner.<ref>[http://smu.edu/tower/ John Goodwin Tower Center], Official website. Retrieved July 2011</ref>
==Medal of Freedom== The Medal of Freedom is the highest honor the Tower Center bestows. It is awarded in recognition of extraordinary contributions to the advancement of democratic ideals and to the security, prosperity and welfare of humanity. Recipients include: * Former Secretary of State and Chairman of the Joint Chiefs, General [[Colin Powell]] (1997) * Former Prime Minister of Great Britain, Lady [[Margaret Thatcher]] (1999) * The 41st President of the United States, [[George H.W. Bush]] (2001) * General [[Tommy Franks]] (2003) * Senator [[John McCain]] (2006) * Prime Minister [[Tony Blair]] (2008) * The 43rd President of the United States, [[George W. '''Kathleen Marie Kelly''' (born October 29, 1980), known as '''Kate Kelly''', is an American [[Mormon feminism|Mormon feminist]]<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sltrib.com/home/4042513-155/two-years-after-kate-kellys-excommunication|title=Two years after an excommunicated Kate Kelly sought a giant leap, Mormon feminists keep making small steps toward equity|last=Tribune|first=Peggy Fletcher Stack The Salt Lake|work=The Salt Lake Tribune|access-date=2017-05-25|language=en-US}}</ref> and human rights attorney who founded [[Ordain Women]], an organization advocating for the [[ordination of women]] to the [[Priesthood (LDS Church)|priesthood]] in [[The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints]] (LDS Church). Kelly was [[Excommunication#The_Church_of_Jesus_Christ_of_Latter-day_Saints|excommunicated]] from the LDS Church in 2014.
==Early life and education== Kelly was born in 1980 in Arizona to Jim and Donna Kelly as the first of four children. She grew up in [[Hood River, Oregon]], with both her parents working outside the home. Both parents were converts to the LDS Church, and her father at one time served as [[bishop (Latter Day Saints)|bishop]] of a local congregation.<ref name=Marostica2014>{{cite news |last= Marostica |first= Laura |title= Feminism in Faith: Kate Kelly's Mission to Ordain Mormon Women |url= https://www.buzzfeed.com/lauradomenica/feminism-in-faith-mormonism |newspaper= BuzzFeed BuzzReads |date= March 7, 2014}}</ref>
Kelly graduated from [[Brigham Young University]] (BYU) with a [[Bachelor of Arts]] degree in [[political science]] in 2006.<ref name=siz>{{citation |url= http://sistasinzion.com/2014/01/ordain-women-kate-kelly-suzette-smith.html |title= Ordain Women (Kate Kelly & Suzette Smith) |author= "Sista Beehive and Sista Laurel" |date= January 26, 2014 |work= SistasInZion.com |publisher= Sistas in Zion }}</ref> She served an 18-month [[Missionary (LDS Church)|LDS mission]] in [[Barcelona]], Spain. While at BYU, she organized a campus protest of nearly 100 students concerning the firing of a university employee for criticizing student elections.<ref name=Marostica2014/><ref name=KSL1>{{cite news |title= BYU Students Protest Firing |url= http://www.ksl.com/?nid=148&sid=184927 |work= KSL.com |publisher= [[KSL-TV]]/[[KSL (radio)|KSL News Radio]] |agency= [[Associated Press|AP]] |date= April 1, 2006}}</ref> Kelly went on to earn a law degree from [[American University Washington College of Law|American University]] in 2012.<ref name="siz"/>
Kelly married J. Neil Ransom in the [[Salt Lake Temple]] in 2006.<ref name=SLT2>{{cite news |last= Stack |first= Peggy Fletcher |authorlink= Peggy Fletcher Stack |title= Mormon Bishopric Wants More Time to Decide Kate Kelly's Fate |url= http://www.sltrib.com/sltrib/news/58099754-78/kelly-church-women-lds.html.csp |newspaper= [[The Salt Lake Tribune]] |date= June 22, 2014}}</ref> The couple were "[[childless by choice]]".<ref>{{cite web |last=Kelly |first=Kate |url=http://mormonstories.org/neil-ransom-and-kate-kelly-after-kates-excommunication/ |title=488-490: Neil Ransom and Kate Kelly – After Kate's Excommunication | work=Momron Stories Podcast}}</ref> In September 2015, Kelly joined [[Planned Parenthood]] as a strategic advocate and policy counsel.<ref>{{cite web|author=ANNIE KNOX and Rachel Piper The Salt Lake Tribune |url=http://www.sltrib.com/home/2958605-155/ex-ordain-women-leader-kate-kelly-joins |title=Ex-Ordain Women leader Kate Kelly joins Planned Parenthood of Utah | The Salt Lake Tribune |publisher=Sltrib.com |date= |accessdate=2015-11-24}}</ref>
On March 14, 2016 Kate Kelly confirmed she had divorced her husband, J. Neil Ransom, and had started a relationship with Jack Waters.<ref>{{cite web |last=Kelly |first=Kate |url=https://www.mormonstories.org/podcast/kate-kelly-on-life-after-excommunication-safe-sex-and-womens-reproductive-rights/ |title=Mormon Stories: 624: Kate Kelly on Life after Excommunication, Safe Sex, And Women's Reproductive Rights</ref>
==Ordain Women== In May 2013, Kelly founded [[Ordain Women]], an organization advocating for the [[ordination of women]] to the [[Priesthood (LDS Church)|priesthood]] in the LDS Church.<ref>{{cite web|author=Peggy Fletcher stack and Michael McFall The Salt Lake Tribune |url=http://www.sltrib.com/home/2694608-155/kate-kelly-out-as-leader-of |title=Kate Kelly out as leader of Mormon group Ordain Women | The Salt Lake Tribune |publisher=Sltrib.com |date= |accessdate=2015-11-24}}</ref> Kelly was requested by local church leaders to cease her campaign.<ref name=walch20140611>{{cite news|last1=Walch|first1=Tad|title=Two Mormon activists say they are facing church discipline |url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/865604976/Two-Mormon-activists-say-they-are-facing-church-discipline.html?pg=all|accessdate=April 25, 2015|newspaper=Deseret News|date=June 11, 2014}}</ref><ref name="apps.washingtonpost.com">{{cite web|url=https://apps.washingtonpost.com/g/page/local/letter-to-kate-kelly/1118/ |title=Letter to Kate Kelly - The Washington Post |publisher=Apps.washingtonpost.com |date=2014-06-30 |accessdate=2015-11-24}}</ref> Kelly subsequently demonstrated on [[Temple Square]] during the church's April 2014 [[General Conference (LDS Church)|General Conference]],<ref name=walch20140611/> after which she was [[Excommunication#The_Church_of_Jesus_Christ_of_Latter-day_Saints|excommunicated]] in June 2014 ''in absentia'' after declining to attend a disciplinary council.<ref name=Walsh>{{citation |first= Tad |last= Walsh |url= http://www.deseretnews.com/article/865605646/LDS-bishop-excommunicates-Ordain-Women-founder.html |title= LDS bishop excommunicates Ordain Women founder |newspaper= [[Deseret News]] |date= June 23, 2014}}</ref>
In the weeks before and after her excommunication, Kelly urged followers to stay in the church and "raise hell" if they could do so while maintaining their mental and emotional health.<ref>{{citation |last=Kelly |first=Kate |url=http://feministmormonhousewivespodcast.org/episode-112-kate-kelly-on-being-disciplined-by-the-church-of-jesus-chris-of-latter-day-saints/ |title=Episode 112: Kate Kelly on Being Disciplined by The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints | work=Feminist Mormon Housewives Podcast}}</ref><ref name="YouTube">{{citation |title= Kate Kelly of Ordain Women speaks about her excommunication from the LDS (Mormon) Church |url= https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hFHf1UZGne8 |date= June 24, 2014 |publisher= [[The Salt Lake Tribune]] }}</ref> She appealed her excommunication, first to her stake president,<ref>{{citation |title= Kate Kelly appeals excommunication from Mormon church |url= http://www.sltrib.com/sltrib/lifestyle/58221626-80/kelly-church-women-ordain.html.csp |first= Nate |last= Carlisle |date= July 24, 2014 |newspaper= The Salt Lake Tribune }}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= Kate Kelly’s Appeal to Her Stake President |url= http://ordainwomen.org/kate-kellys-appeal-to-her-stake-president/ |date= July 23, 2014 |author= "Nancy" |work= Ordainwomen.org }}</ref> then to the [[First Presidency (LDS Church)|First Presidency]], all of whom rejected the appeal.<ref>{{citation |title= Kelly loses appeal, keeps fighting for Mormon membership |url= http://www.sltrib.com/home/1769366-155/kelly-appeal-church-wheatley-decision-women |date= October 31, 2014 |last= Stack |first= Peggy Fletcher |authorlink= Peggy Fletcher Stack |newspaper= The Salt Lake Tribune }}</ref><ref>{{citation |title= Ordain Women’s Kate Kelly loses last appeal; husband to resign from Mormon church |url= http://www.sltrib.com/lifestyle/faith/2233333-155/ordain-womens-kate-kelly-loses-last |first= Peggy Fletcher|last= Stack |date= February 28, 2015 |authorlink= Peggy Fletcher Stack |newspaper= The Salt Lake Tribune }}</ref>
Kelly no longer claims any religious affiliation,<ref name="rel">{{cite podcast| url=http://theletsgoeatshow.com/2016/06/13/kate-kelly/| title=The Let's Go Eat Show| website=The Let's Go Eat Show| host=Bill Allred| date=2016-06-13| time=3:37| access-date=2016-06-14}}</ref> but participated in the ordination of a [[ordination of women and the Catholic Church| female Roman Catholic priest]] in October 2015.<ref>{{cite web|author=Kristen Moulton The Salt Lake Tribune |url=http://www.sltrib.com/home/3075882-155/salt-lake-city-woman-is-first |title=Salt Lake City woman is first in Utah to claim ordination to Catholic priesthood | The Salt Lake Tribune |publisher=Sltrib.com |date= |accessdate=2015-11-24}}</ref>
In an interview with John Dehlin, Kate confirmed she no longer has a belief in The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints.<ref>{{cite web |last=Kelly |first=Kate |url=https://www.mormonstories.org/podcast/kate-kelly-on-life-after-excommunication-safe-sex-and-womens-reproductive-rights/ |title=Mormon Stories: 624: Kate Kelly on Life after Excommunication, Safe Sex, And Women's Reproductive Rights</ref>

{{refimprove|date=May 2012}} A '''leadership style''' is a [[leader]]'s method of providing direction, implementing plans, and [[motivation|motivating]] people.{{citation needed|date=January 2016}} Various authors have proposed identifying many different [[leadership]] styles as exhibited by leaders in the [[politics | political]], [[commerce | business]] or other fields. Studies on leadership style are conducted{{by whom?|date=April 2017}} in the [[military]] field, expressing an approach that stresses a [[holistic]] view of [[leadership]], including how a leader's physical presence determines how others perceive that leader. The factors of physical presence in this context include military bearing, physical fitness, confidence, and resilience. The leader's intellectual capacity helps to conceptualize solutions and to acquire knowledge to do the job.{{cn|date=April 2017}} A leader's conceptual abilities apply agility, judgment, innovation, interpersonal tact, and [[domain knowledge]]. Domain knowledge encompasses tactical and technical knowledge as well as cultural and geopolitical awareness.<ref name="Army 10-2006">{{cite book |publisher=Headquarters, Department of the Army |title=Army Leadership. Competent, Confident, and Agile |page=18 |location=[[Washington, D.C.]] |url=http://cdm16635.contentdm.oclc.org/cdm/ref/collection/p16635coll8/id/55579 |date=12 October 2006}} Publication available at Army Knowledge Online (www.us.army.mil) and General Dennis J. Reimer Training and Doctrine Digital Library at (www.train.army.mil), FM 6–22.</ref>{{qn|date=April 2017}} Daniel Goleman (2000) in his article "Leadership that Gets Results" talks about six styles of leadership.<ref name="HBR"> {{cite web |title=Leadership that Gets Results |work=[[Harvard Business Review]] |url=https://hbr.org/2000/03/leadership-that-gets-results |access-date=June 24, 2016}}</ref>
==Authoritarian== The [[authoritative]] leadership style keeps main emphasis on the distinction of the authoritarian leader and their followers. These types of leaders make sure to only create a distinct [[professional]] relationship. Direct [[supervision]] is what they believe to be key in maintaining a successful environment and follower ship. Authoritarian leadership styles often follow the vision of those that are in control, and may not necessarily be compatible with those that are being led. Authoritarian leaders have a focus on efficiency, as other styles, such as a democratic style, may be seen as a hindrance on progress. Examples of authoritarian leadership: a police officer directing traffic, a teacher ordering a student to do his or her assignment, and a supervisor instructing a subordinate to clean a workstation. All of these positions require a distinct set of characteristics that give the leader the position to get things in order or get a point across. Authoritarian Traits: sets goals individually, engages primarily in one-way and downward communication, controls discussion with followers, and dominate interaction.{{citation needed|date=October 2018}}
Several studies have confirmed a relationship between [[bullying]], on the one hand, and an autocratic leadership and an authoritarian way of settling [[Organizational conflict|conflicts]] or dealing with disagreements, on the other. An authoritarian style of leadership may create a [[climate of fear]], where there is little or no room for dialogue and where complaining may be considered futile.<ref name="SalinHelge2010">{{citation |author1=Salin, D. |author2=Helge, H. |chapter=Organizational Causes of Workplace Bullying |title=Bullying and Harassment in the Workplace: Developments in Theory, Research, and Practice |publisher= |year=2010}}</ref>
==Paternalistic== The way a paternalistic leader works is by acting as a parental figure by taking care of their subordinates as a parent would. In this style of leadership the leader supplies complete concern for his followers or workers. In return he receives the complete trust and loyalty of his people. Workers under this style of leader are expected to become totally committed to what the leader believes and will not strive off and work independently. The relationship between these co-workers and leader are extremely solid. The workers are expected to stay with a company for a longer period of time because of the loyalty and trust. Not only do they treat each other like family inside the work force, but outside too. These workers are able to go to each other with any problems they have regarding something because they believe in what they say is going to truly help them.<ref name="ErbenGuneser">{{cite journal|last=Erben and Guneser|first=Gul and Ayse|title=The Relationship Between Paternalistic Leadership and Organizational Commitement:Investigating the Role of Climate Regarding ethics|journal=Journal of Business Ethics|date=November 2008|volume=82|issue=4|pages=955–968|url=https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007%2Fs10551-007-9605-z?LI=true|accessdate=2012-12-01|doi=10.1007/s10551-007-9605-z}}</ref>
One of the downsides to a paternalistic leader is that the leader could start to play favorites in decisions. This leader would include the workers more apt to follow and start to exclude the ones who were less loyal. In today's market paternalism is more difficult to come by according to Padavic and Earnest who wrote "business dimensional and Organizational Counseling." They believe this because there have become more lay-offs and stronger unionization. This affects paternalistic leaders because the co-workers may not believe that their jobs are 100% ensured. When this happens, workers begin to look for bigger and better job opportunities instead of staying at one company for a longer period of time. Because of this, the leader may be thinking that you could be leaving and not fully believe you when you tell them something about a job opportunity. This could put the workers and leader at risk for a bad situation.<ref name="ErbenGuneser"/>
According to B. M. Bass, who wrote ''Leadership and Performance Beyond Expectations'', workers who follow paternalistic leadership also have better organization skills. The leader encourages organization because they allow the workers to complete tasks so that they can stay on top of their work. The workers complete tasks this boosts self-confidence and it makes them work harder to reach a goal and exceed the goal to prove to their boss they are working hard. Having this style of leadership can also help implement a reward system. This system will allow their workers to work even better because there is something for them at the end of the tunnel. While doing this they will also be able to accomplish more work in a set time frame.<ref name="ErbenGuneser" />
==Democratic== The [[democracy|democratic]] leadership style consists of the leader sharing the [[decision-making]] abilities with group members by promoting the interests of the group members and by practicing [[social equality]].<ref name="Foster2002"> {{cite journal |last=Foster |first=D. E. |year=2002 |title=A Method of Comparing Follower Satisfaction with the Authoritarian, Democratic, and Laissez-faire Styles of Leadership |journal=Communication Teacher |volume=16 |number=2 |pages=4–6}}</ref>
The boundaries of democratic participation tend to be circumscribed by the organization or the group needs and the instrumental value of people's attributes (skills, attitudes, etc.). The democratic style encompasses the notion that everyone, by virtue of their human status, should play a part in the group's decisions. However, the democratic style of leadership still requires guidance and control by a specific leader. The democratic style demands the leader to make decisions on who should be called upon within the group and who is given the right to participate in, make and vote on decisions.<ref name="Woods2010">{{cite journal |last=Woods |first=A. P. |year=2010 |title=Democratic leadership: drawing distinctions with distributed leadership |journal=International Journal of Leadership in Education |volume=7 |number=1 |pages=3–36}}</ref>
Research has found that this leadership style is one of the most effective and creates higher productivity, better contributions from group members and increased group morale. Democratic leadership can lead to better ideas and more creative solutions to problems because group members are encouraged to share their thoughts and ideas. While democratic leadership is one of the most effective leadership styles, it does have some potential downsides. In situations where roles are unclear or time is of the essence, democratic leadership can lead to communication failures and uncompleted projects. Democratic leadership works best in situations where group members are skilled and eager to share their knowledge. It is also important to have plenty of time to allow people to contribute, develop a plan and then vote on the best course of action.<ref name=Martindale>{{cite journal |last=Martindale |first=N |year=2011 |title=Leadership Styles: How to handle the different personas |journal=Strategic Communication Management |volume=15 |number=8 |pages=32–35}}</ref>
==Laissez-faire== The [[laissez-faire]] leadership style is where all the rights and power to make decisions is fully given to the worker. This was first described by Lewin, Lippitt, and White in 1939, along with the autocratic leadership and the democratic leadership styles.<ref name="Wren2013">{{cite book|author=Kevin Wren|title=Social Influences|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=eGhwpXpTG8cC&pg=PA75|date=15 April 2013|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-134-66357-6|pages=75}}</ref>
Laissez-faire leaders allow followers to have complete freedom to make decisions concerning the completion of their work. It allows followers a [[self-rule]], while at the same time offering guidance and support when requested. The laissez-faire leader using guided freedom provides the followers with all materials necessary to accomplish their goals, but does not directly participate in decision making unless the followers request their assistance.<ref name=essortment>{{cite web |title=Styles Of Leadership |publisher=Essortment |access-date=March 16, 2012 |url=http://www.essortment.com/styles-leadership-36149.html}}</ref>{{unreliable source?|date=March 2012}}
This is an effective style to use when: * Followers are highly skilled, experienced, and educated. * Followers have pride in their work and the drive to do it successfully on their own. * Outside experts, such as staff specialists or consultants are being used. * Followers are trustworthy and experienced.
This style should ''not'' be used when: * The leader cannot or will not provide regular feedback to their followers.<ref name=essortment/>
== Transactional == {{Main article|Transactional leadership}}
<!-- Commented out: Transactional leaders focus their leadership on motivating followers through a system of rewards and punishments. There are two factors which form the basis for this system, [[Contingent]] Reward and management-by-exception.{{citation needed|date=January 2015}} * Contingent reward provides rewards, materialistic or psychological, for effort and recognizes good performance. * Management-by-exception allows the leader to maintain the status quo. The leader intervenes when subordinates do not meet acceptable performance levels and initiates corrective action to improve performance. Management by exception helps reduce the workload of managers being that they are only called-in when workers deviate from course.
This type of leader identifies the needs of their followers and gives rewards to satisfy those needs in exchange for a certain level of performance. Transactional leaders focus on increasing the efficiency of established routines and procedures. They are more concerned with following existing rules than with making changes to the organization. A transactional leader establishes and standardizes practices that will help the organization reach:{{citation needed|date=October 2018}} *Maturity *[[Goal-setting]] *Efficiency of operation *Increasing productivity. -->
===Effect on work teams=== Survey done by Jun Liu, Xiaoyu Liu and Xianju Zeng<ref name="Lio_al2011">{{cite journal |last1=Liu |first1=J. |last2=Liu |first2=X. |last3=Zeng |first3=X. |year=2011 |title=Does transactional leadership count for team innovativeness? |journal=Journal of Organizational Change Management |volume=24 |issue=3 |pages=282–298 |url= |doi=10.1108/09534811111132695}}</ref> on the correlation between transactional leadership and how innovations can be affected by team emotions. The research was composed of 90 work teams, with a total of 460 members and 90 team leaders. The study found that there is a relationship between emotions, labor behavior and transactional leadership that affects the team. Depending on the level of emotions of the team; this can affect the transactional leader in a positive or negative way. Transactional leaders work better in teams where there is a lower level of emotions going into the project. This is because individuals are able to: *Think freely when setting their emotions aside from their work. *Have all of their focus on the given task.
A transactional leader is: #Negatively affected when the emotional level is high. #Positively affected when the emotional level is low.
Transactional leadership presents a form of strategic leadership that is important for the organization's development. Transactional leadership is essential for team innovativeness.
==Transformational== A [[transformational leadership|transformational leader]] is a type of person in which the leader is not limited by his or her followers' perception.<ref name="Schultz&Schultz1998">{{cite book |last1=Schultz |first1=Duane P. |last2=Schultz |first2=Sydney Ellen |year=1998 |chapter=Chapter 7: Leadership |title=Psychology and Work Today |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=9HSACgAAQBAJ |edition=10 |location=Abingdon, Oxfordshire |publisher=Routledge |publication-date=2015 |page= |isbn=978-1-3173-5080-4 |access-date=2016-05-22 |quote=Transformational leadership[:] A leadership style in which leaders are not constrained by their followers' perceptions but are free to act to change or transform their followers' views.}}</ref><ref name="Schultz&Schultz2010NJ">{{cite book |last=Schultz |first=Duane P. Schultz, Sydney Ellen |title=Psychology and work today : An introduction to industrial and organizational psychology |year=2010 |publisher=Prentice Hall |location=[[Upper Saddle River, New Jersey]] |isbn=978-0-2056-8358-1 |page=201 |edition=10th}}</ref> The main objective is to work to ''change'' or ''transform'' his or her followers' ''needs'' and ''redirect'' their thinking. Leaders that follow the transformation style of leading, challenge and inspire their followers with a sense of purpose and excitement.<ref name="Schultz&Schultz2010NY">{{cite book |last1=Schultz |first1=Duane P. |last2=Schultz |first2=Sydney Ellen |title=Psychology and work today |year=2010 |publisher=[[Prentice Hall]] |location=New York |isbn=0-205-68358-4 |pages=201–202}}</ref>
Transformational leaders also create a vision of what they aspire to be, and communicate this idea to others (their followers).{{citation needed|date=May 2016}} Schultz and Schultz identify three characteristics of a transformational leader:<ref name="Schultz&Schultz1998"/><ref name="Schultz&Schultz2010NJ"/><ref name="Schultz&Schultz2010NY"/> * Charismatic leadership has a broad field of knowledge, has a self-promoting personality, high/great energy level, and willing to take risk and use irregular strategies in order to stimulate their followers to think independently * Individualized consideration * Intellectual stimulation
